#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),

  },

  }
)

[Submission]: Looking at the code, I can see that when a secondary axis inherits breaks from a discrete primary scale (via `derive()`), it gets the break values but not their names. To preserve named breaks as labels, we need to modify the `init` method in the `AxisSecondary` ggproto object.

Here's the proposed edit to the `init` method (around line 139):

```r
# Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
init = function(self, scale) {
  if (self$empty()) {
    return()
  }
  transform <- self$trans
  if (!is.function(transform)) {
    cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
  }
  if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
  if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
  if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
      n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
      if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
        self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
      } else {
        self$breaks <- breaks
      }
    }
  }
  if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
  
  # If labels are still waiver and breaks have names, use those names as labels
  if (is.waiver(self$labels) && !is.null(names(self$breaks))) {
    self$labels <- names(self$breaks)
  }
  
  if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
},
```

The key addition is:
```r
# If labels are still waiver and breaks have names, use those names as labels
if (is.waiver(self$labels) && !is.null(names(self$breaks))) {
  self$labels <- names(self$breaks)
}
```

This code checks if:
1. Labels haven't been explicitly set (still `waiver()`)
2. The breaks have names

If both conditions are true, it uses the break names as labels. This will work for both:
- When breaks are inherited via `derive()` from a discrete scale
- When breaks are explicitly provided as a named vector

This ensures that named discrete breaks will automatically use their names as labels on the secondary axis, matching the behavior users would expect.
***

      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } 
```

...should be changed to:

```
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- setNames(scale$get_breaks())
      } 
```

and, later, on:

```
    else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }
```

can be changed to:

```
    else {
      breaks <- setNames(scale$map(self$breaks), names(self$breaks))
    }
```

That's all that's needed, but both changes are needed.

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )

      }
    }

    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation

    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)

  },

#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),

    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

content.text:
Here's a file implementing secondary axes in ggplot2:

```
#' Specify a secondary axis
#'
#' This function is used in conjunction with a position scale to create a
#' secondary axis, positioned opposite of the primary axis. All secondary
#' axes must be based on a one-to-one transformation of the primary axes.
#'
#' @param transform A formula or function of a strictly monotonic transformation
#'
#' @param trans `r lifecycle::badge("deprecated")`
#'
#' @param name The name of the secondary axis
#'
#' @param breaks One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no breaks
#'   - `waiver()` for the default breaks computed by the transformation object
#'   - A numeric vector of positions
#'   - A function that takes the limits as input and returns breaks as output
#'
#' @param labels One of:
#'   - `NULL` for no labels
#'   - `waiver()` for the default labels computed by the transformation object
#'   - A character vector giving labels (must be same length as `breaks`)
#'   - A function that takes the breaks as input and returns labels as output
#'
#' @param guide A position guide that will be used to render
#'   the axis on the plot. Usually this is [guide_axis()].
#'
#' @details
#' `sec_axis()` is used to create the specifications for a secondary axis.
#' Except for the `trans` argument any of the arguments can be set to
#' `derive()` which would result in the secondary axis inheriting the
#' settings from the primary axis.
#'
#' `dup_axis()` is provide as a shorthand for creating a secondary axis that
#' is a duplication of the primary axis, effectively mirroring the primary axis.
#'
#' As of v3.1, date and datetime scales have limited secondary axis capabilities.
#' Unlike other continuous scales, secondary axis transformations for date and datetime scales
#' must respect their primary POSIX data structure.
#' This means they may only be transformed via addition or subtraction, e.g.
#' `~ . + hms::hms(days = 8)`, or
#' `~ . - 8*60*60`. Nonlinear transformations will return an error.
#' To produce a time-since-event secondary axis in this context, users
#' may consider adapting secondary axis labels.
#'
#' @examples
#' p <- ggplot(mtcars, aes(cyl, mpg)) +
#'   geom_point()
#'
#' # Create a simple secondary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10))
#'
#' # Inherit the name from the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous("Miles/gallon", sec.axis = sec_axis(~ . + 10, name = derive()))
#'
#' # Duplicate the primary axis
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = dup_axis())
#'
#' # You can pass in a formula as a shorthand
#' p + scale_y_continuous(sec.axis = ~ .^2)
#'
#' # Secondary axes work for date and datetime scales too:
#' df <- data.frame(
#'   dx = seq(
#'     as.POSIXct("2012-02-29 12:00:00", tz = "UTC"),
#'     length.out = 10,
#'     by = "4 hour"
#'   ),
#'   price = seq(20, 200000, length.out = 10)
#'  )
#'
#' # This may useful for labelling different time scales in the same plot
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime(
#'     "Date",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d",
#'     date_breaks = "6 hour",
#'     sec.axis = dup_axis(
#'       name = "Time of Day",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' # or to transform axes for different timezones
#' ggplot(df, aes(x = dx, y = price)) +
#'   geom_line() +
#'   scale_x_datetime("
#'     GMT",
#'     date_labels = "%b %d %I %p",
#'     sec.axis = sec_axis(
#'       ~ . + 8 * 3600,
#'       name = "GMT+8",
#'       labels = scales::label_time("%b %d %I %p")
#'     )
#'   )
#'
#' @export
sec_axis <- function(transform = NULL,
                     name = waiver(), breaks = waiver(), labels = waiver(),
                     guide = waiver(), trans = deprecated()) {
  if (lifecycle::is_present(trans)) {
    deprecate_soft0("3.5.0", "sec_axis(trans)", "sec_axis(transform)")
    transform <- trans
  }

  # sec_axis() historically accepted two-sided formula, so be permissive.
  if (length(transform) > 2) transform <- transform[c(1,3)]

  transform <- as_function(transform)
  ggproto(NULL, AxisSecondary,
    trans = transform,
    name = name,
    breaks = breaks,
    labels = labels,
    guide = guide
  )
}
#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
dup_axis <- function(transform = identity, name = derive(), breaks = derive(),
                     labels = derive(), guide = derive(), trans = deprecated()) {
  sec_axis(transform, trans = trans, name, breaks, labels, guide)
}

is.sec_axis <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "AxisSecondary")
}

set_sec_axis <- function(sec.axis, scale) {
  if (!is.waiver(sec.axis)) {
    if (scale$is_discrete()) {
      if (!identical(.subset2(sec.axis, "trans"), identity)) {
        cli::cli_abort("Discrete secondary axes must have the {.fn identity} transformation.")
      }
    }
    if (is.formula(sec.axis)) sec.axis <- sec_axis(sec.axis)
    if (!is.sec_axis(sec.axis)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Secondary axes must be specified using {.fn sec_axis}.")
    }
    scale$secondary.axis <- sec.axis
  }
  return(scale)
}

#' @rdname sec_axis
#'
#' @export
derive <- function() {
  structure(list(), class = "derived")
}
is.derived <- function(x) {
  inherits(x, "derived")
}
#' @rdname ggplot2-ggproto
#' @format NULL
#' @usage NULL
#' @export
AxisSecondary <- ggproto("AxisSecondary", NULL,
  trans = NULL,
  axis = NULL,
  name = waiver(),
  breaks = waiver(),
  labels = waiver(),

  # This determines the quality of the remapping from the secondary axis and
  # back to the primary axis i.e. the exactness of the placement of the
  # breakpoints of the secondary axis.
  detail = 1000,

  empty = function(self) {
    is.null(self$trans)
  },

  # Inherit settings from the primary axis/scale
  init = function(self, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) {
      return()
    }
    transform <- self$trans
    if (!is.function(transform)) {
      cli::cli_abort("Transformation for secondary axes must be a function.")
    }
    if (is.derived(self$name) && !is.waiver(scale$name)) self$name <- scale$name
    if (is.derived(self$breaks)) self$breaks <- scale$breaks
    if (is.waiver(self$breaks)) {
      if (scale$is_discrete()) {
        self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()
      } else {
        breaks <- scale$get_transformation()$breaks
        n_breaks <- scale$n.breaks
        if (!is.null(n_breaks) && "n" %in% fn_fmls_names(breaks)) {
          self$breaks <- function(x) breaks(x, n = n_breaks)
        } else {
          self$breaks <- breaks
        }
      }
    }
    if (is.derived(self$labels)) self$labels <- scale$labels
    if (is.derived(self$guide)) self$guide <- scale$guide
  },

  transform_range = function(self, range) {
    self$trans(range)
  },

  mono_test = function(self, scale){
    range <- scale$range$range

    # Check if plot is empty
    if (is.null(range)) {
      return()
    }

    transformation <- scale$get_transformation()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Test for monotonicity
    if (!is_unique(sign(diff(full_range))))
      cli::cli_abort(
        "Transformation for secondary axes must be strictly monotonic."
      )
  },

  break_info = function(self, range, scale) {
    if (self$empty()) return()

    # Test for monotonicity on unexpanded range
    if (!scale$is_discrete()) {
      self$mono_test(scale)
      breaks <- self$breaks
    } else {
      breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)
    }

    # Get scale's original range before transformation
    transformation <- scale$get_transformation() %||% transform_identity()
    along_range <- seq(range[1], range[2], length.out = self$detail)
    old_range <- transformation$inverse(along_range)

    # Create mapping between primary and secondary range
    full_range <- self$transform_range(old_range)

    # Remove duplicates in the expanded area of the range that can arise if
    # the transformation is non-monotonic in the expansion. The split ensures
    # the middle duplicated are kept
    duplicates <- c(
      !duplicated(full_range[seq_len(self$detail/2)], fromLast = TRUE),
      !duplicated(full_range[-seq_len(self$detail/2)])
    )
    old_range <- old_range[duplicates]
    full_range <- full_range[duplicates]

    # Get break info for the secondary axis
    new_range <- range(full_range, na.rm = TRUE)

    # patch for date and datetime scales just to maintain functionality
    # works only for linear secondary transforms that respect the time or date transform
    if (transformation$name %in% c("date", "time")) {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, transformation = transformation)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()
      old_val_trans <- rescale(range_info$major, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
      old_val_minor_trans <- rescale(range_info$minor, from = c(0, 1), to = range)
    } else {
      temp_scale <- self$create_scale(new_range, breaks = breaks)
      range_info <- temp_scale$break_info()

      # Map the break values back to their correct position on the primary scale
      if (length(range_info$major_source) > 0) {
        old_val <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$major_source)$y
        old_val_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val)

        # rescale values from 0 to 1
        range_info$major[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_trans, range(old_val_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_trans <- NULL
      }

      if (length(range_info$minor_source) > 0) {
        old_val_minor <- stats::approx(full_range, old_range, range_info$minor_source)$y
        old_val_minor_trans <- transformation$transform(old_val_minor)

        range_info$minor[] <- round(
          rescale(
            scale$map(old_val_minor_trans, range(old_val_minor_trans)),
            from = range
          ),
          digits = 3
        )
      } else {
        old_val_minor_trans <- NULL
      }
    }

    # The _source values should be in (primary) scale_transformed space,
    # so that the coord doesn't have to know about the secondary scale transformation
    # when drawing the axis. The values in user space are useful for testing.
    range_info$major_source_user <- range_info$major_source
    range_info$minor_source_user <- range_info$minor_source
    range_info$major_source[] <- old_val_trans
    range_info$minor_source[] <- old_val_minor_trans

    names(range_info) <- paste0("sec.", names(range_info))
    range_info
  },

  # Temporary scale for the purpose of calling break_info()
  create_scale = function(self, range, transformation = transform_identity(),
                          breaks = self$breaks) {
    scale <- ggproto(NULL, ScaleContinuousPosition,
                     name = self$name,
                     breaks = breaks,
                     labels = self$labels,
                     limits = range,
                     expand = c(0, 0),
                     trans  = transformation
    )
    scale$train(range)
    scale
  },
  make_title = function(title) {
    title
  }
)
```

input.content:
I need to evaluate whether the submitted solution implements the needed changes according to the criterion.

The criterion states that two specific changes are needed:

1. In the `init` method, change `self$breaks <- scale$get_breaks()` to `self$breaks <- setNames(scale$get_breaks())` for discrete scales
2. In the `break_info` method, change `breaks <- scale$map(self$breaks)` to `breaks <- setNames(scale$map(self$breaks), names(self$breaks))` to preserve names during mapping

The submission instead proposes a different approach. It adds a new condition after setting the labels that checks if:
- Labels are still a waiver (default)
- Breaks have names

And if both are true, it sets the labels to be the names of the breaks.

While this solution might work in some cases, it doesn't properly address the core issue identified in the criterion. The criterion specifically points out that the names on the breaks are being lost during two different operations and need to be preserved at those points. 

The submitted solution doesn't make either of the two specific changes required by the criterion. It attempts to work around the issue by applying names after they've already been lost, rather than preventing the loss in the first place.

GRADE: I

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.
samples.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
I need to find the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arr_delay values among planes that have flown at least 100 flights.

Here's the tidyverse code to solve this:

```r
library(tidyverse)

flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    n_flights = n(),
    n_na_arr_delay = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na = n_na_arr_delay / n_flights
  ) %>%
  filter(n_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(prop_na)) %>%
  slice(1)
```

This code:
1. Groups flights by `tailnum`
2. For each tailnum, calculates:
   - Total number of flights (`n_flights`)
   - Number of flights with NA arr_delay (`n_na_arr_delay`)
   - Proportion of NA arr_delays (`prop_na`)
3. Filters to only include tailnums with at least 100 flights
4. Arranges in descending order by proportion of NAs
5. Takes the first row (highest proportion)

The result will show the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arrival delays among planes that have flown at least 100 times.

***
[Submission]: I need to find the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arr_delay values among planes that have flown at least 100 flights.

Here's the tidyverse code to solve this:

```r
library(tidyverse)

flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    n_flights = n(),
    n_na_arr_delay = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na = n_na_arr_delay / n_flights
  ) %>%
  filter(n_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(prop_na)) %>%
  slice(1)
```

This code:
1. Groups flights by `tailnum`
2. For each tailnum, calculates:
   - Total number of flights (`n_flights`)
   - Number of flights with NA arr_delay (`n_na_arr_delay`)
   - Proportion of NA arr_delays (`prop_na`)
3. Filters to only include tailnums with at least 100 flights
4. Arranges in descending order by proportion of NAs
5. Takes the first row (highest proportion)

The result will show the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arrival delays among planes that have flown at least 100 times.
***
[Criterion]: There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.
***

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

content.text:
I need to find the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arr_delay values among planes that have flown at least 100 flights.

Here's the tidyverse code to solve this:

```r
library(tidyverse)

flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    n_flights = n(),
    n_na_arr_delay = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na = n_na_arr_delay / n_flights
  ) %>%
  filter(n_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(prop_na)) %>%
  slice(1)
```

This code:
1. Groups flights by `tailnum`
2. For each tailnum, calculates:
   - Total number of flights (`n_flights`)
   - Number of flights with NA arr_delay (`n_na_arr_delay`)
   - Proportion of NA arr_delays (`prop_na`)
3. Filters to only include tailnums with at least 100 flights
4. Arranges in descending order by proportion of NAs
5. Takes the first row (highest proportion)

The result will show the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arrival delays among planes that have flown at least 100 times.

events.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

[Submission]: I need to find the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arrival delays among planes that have flown at least 100 flights.

Here's the tidyverse code to solve this:

```r
library(tidyverse)

flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarise(
    n_flights = n(),
    n_na_arr_delay = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na = n_na_arr_delay / n_flights
  ) %>%
  filter(n_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(prop_na)) %>%
  slice(1)
```

This code:
1. Groups flights by `tailnum`
2. For each tailnum, calculates:
   - Total number of flights (`n_flights`)
   - Number of flights with NA arrival delays (`n_na_arr_delay`)
   - Proportion of NA arrival delays (`prop_na`)
3. Filters to only include tailnums with at least 100 flights
4. Arranges in descending order by proportion of NA values
5. Takes the first row (the tailnum with the highest proportion)

If you want just the tailnum value, you can add `%>% pull(tailnum)` at the end.
***
[Criterion]: There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

Here's the tidyverse code to solve this:

```r
library(tidyverse)

flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarise(
    n_flights = n(),
    n_na_arr_delay = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na = n_na_arr_delay / n_flights
  ) %>%
  filter(n_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(prop_na)) %>%
  slice(1)
```

This code:
1. Groups flights by `tailnum`
2. For each tailnum, calculates:
   - Total number of flights (`n_flights`)
   - Number of flights with NA arrival delays (`n_na_arr_delay`)
   - Proportion of NA arrival delays (`prop_na`)
3. Filters to only include tailnums with at least 100 flights
4. Arranges in descending order by proportion of NA values
5. Takes the first row (the tailnum with the highest proportion)

If you want just the tailnum value, you can add `%>% pull(tailnum)` at the end.

events.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.
***
[Submission]: I need to find the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arr_delay values among planes that have flown at least 100 flights.

```r
library(tidyverse)

flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarise(
    n_flights = n(),
    n_na_arr_delay = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na = n_na_arr_delay / n_flights
  ) %>%
  filter(n_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(prop_na)) %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code:
1. Groups flights by tailnum
2. Calculates for each tailnum:
   - Total number of flights
   - Number of flights with NA arr_delay
   - Proportion of NA arr_delay
3. Filters to only include planes with at least 100 flights
4. Arranges by proportion of NA in descending order
5. Takes the first row (highest proportion)
6. Extracts just the tailnum value
***
[Criterion]: There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.
***

Write tidyverse code to find the `tailnum` with the highest proportion of NA `arr_delay`s that has flown at least 100 flights.

I need to find the tailnum with the highest proportion of NA arr_delay values among planes that have flown at least 100 flights.

```r
library(tidyverse)

flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarise(
    n_flights = n(),
    n_na_arr_delay = sum(is.na(arr_delay)),
    prop_na = n_na_arr_delay / n_flights
  ) %>%
  filter(n_flights >= 100) %>%
  arrange(desc(prop_na)) %>%
  slice(1) %>%
  pull(tailnum)
```

This code:
1. Groups flights by tailnum
2. Calculates for each tailnum:
   - Total number of flights
   - Number of flights with NA arr_delay
   - Proportion of NA arr_delay
3. Filters to only include planes with at least 100 flights
4. Arranges by proportion of NA in descending order
5. Takes the first row (highest proportion)
6. Extracts just the tailnum value

events.target:
There are three main steps here:

1) A grouped filter: only keep rows in `flights` that have > 100 rows. Notably, no persistent summarization across rows should happen here. 
2) A grouped summarize: taking `mean(is.na(arr_delay))` will determine the proportion of NA `arr_delay`s. Notably, `mean(arr_delay == "NA")` or `mean(arr_delay == NA)` is not correct.
3) Arrange by the resulting column in descending order.

The `planes` data is irrelevant and should be ignored.

For example:

```
flights %>%
  filter(n() > 100, .by = tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay)), 
    .by = tailnum
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

With the old `group_by()` syntax:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

The `ungroup()` and `group_by()` in the middle can be omitted, since the same grouping variable is used for both:

```
flights %>%
  group_by(tailnum) %>%
  filter(n() > 100) %>%
  summarize(
    mean_na_arr_delay = mean(is.na(arr_delay))
  ) %>%
  arrange(desc(mean_na_arr_delay))
```

Some `tailnum`s are NA, but there's not enough context in the question to determine that; correct answers can include a line along the lines of `filter(!is.na(tailnum))`.

I get an error using `.by` inside `mutate()`

```
Error in `mutate()`:
 In argument: `by = c(id, date)`.

! `by` must be size 2909492 or 1, not 5818984.
```

How do I fix it?
samples.target: From `by = c(id, date)`, we can see that the user actually typed `by` rather than `.by`. They need to use `.by`.

messages.content:
I get an error using `.by` inside `mutate()`

```
Error in `mutate()`:
 In argument: `by = c(id, date)`.
Caused by error:
! `by` must be size 2909492 or 1, not 5818984.
```

How do I fix it?

content.text:
This error occurs because you're trying to use `by` as a column name inside `mutate()`, but `by` is being interpreted as something else (possibly as grouped data with double the expected size).

Here are the most likely fixes:

## 1. If you meant to use `.by` for grouped operations:

The `.by` argument should be outside the column definitions, not inside:

```r
# Wrong
df %>%
  mutate(new_col = something,
         by = c(id, date))  #  This treats 'by' as a column

# Correct
df %>%
  mutate(new_col = something,
         .by = c(id, date))  #  Note the dot: .by
```

## 2. If you're trying to create a column named "by":

Use backticks to avoid conflicts:

```r
df %>%
  mutate(`by` = c(id, date))
```

## 3. If you're trying to do grouped operations:

Here are the correct approaches:

```r
# Option A: Using .by argument (dplyr 1.1.0+)
df %>%
  mutate(new_col = mean(value), 
         .by = c(id, date))

# Option B: Using group_by()
df %>%
  group_by(id, date) %>%
  mutate(new_col = mean(value)) %>%
  ungroup()
```

The error message suggests you have 2,909,492 rows, but `c(id, date)` is creating a vector of 5,818,984 elements (exactly double), which likely means you're concatenating two columns instead of grouping by them.

Could you share your exact code so I can provide a more specific solution?

messages.content:
I get an error using `.by` inside `mutate()`

```
Error in `mutate()`:
 In argument: `by = c(id, date)`.
Caused by error:
! `by` must be size 2909492 or 1, not 5818984.
```

How do I fix it?

content.text:
This error occurs because you're trying to use `by` as a column name inside `mutate()`, but `by` is being interpreted as something else (possibly attempting to use the `.by` argument syntax incorrectly).

Here are the likely fixes:

## Fix 1: If you're trying to create a column named "by"

Use backticks to escape the column name:

```r
df %>%
  mutate(`by` = c(id, date))
```

Or rename it to avoid confusion:

```r
df %>%
  mutate(grouped_by = c(id, date))
```

## Fix 2: If you're trying to use grouped operations

If you want to perform grouped mutations, use `group_by()` before `mutate()`:

```r
df %>%
  group_by(id, date) %>%
  mutate(new_column = some_function())
```

Or if you're using dplyr 1.1.0+, use the `.by` argument correctly:

```r
df %>%
  mutate(new_column = some_function(), .by = c(id, date))
```

## Fix 3: If you're trying to concatenate values

If you want to combine id and date values:

```r
# For creating a new column with combined values
df %>%
  mutate(id_date = paste(id, date, sep = "_"))

# Or using unite from tidyr
df %>%
  unite("id_date", id, date, remove = FALSE)
```

The error message suggests you're trying to combine vectors of different lengths (2,909,492 rows vs 5,818,984 elements), which indicates `c(id, date)` is concatenating two columns into a single vector that's twice as long as your data frame.

messages.content:
I get an error using `.by` inside `mutate()`

```
Error in `mutate()`:
 In argument: `by = c(id, date)`.
Caused by error:
! `by` must be size 2909492 or 1, not 5818984.
```

How do I fix it?

content.text:
This error occurs because you're trying to use `by` as a column name inside `mutate()`, but `by` is not meant to be used this way. The error suggests you're trying to create a column with values from `c(id, date)`, which doubles the length of your data.

Here are the likely fixes depending on what you're trying to do:

## If you're trying to group operations within mutate:

Use `.by` parameter (dplyr 1.1.0+):
```r
df %>%
  mutate(
    new_col = some_function(value),
    .by = c(id, date)
  )
```

Or use `group_by()` before `mutate()`:
```r
df %>%
  group_by(id, date) %>%
  mutate(new_col = some_function(value)) %>%
  ungroup()
```

## If you're trying to create a new column called "by":

Rename your variable:
```r
df %>%
  mutate(
    group_var = paste(id, date),  # or whatever operation you intended
  )
```

## Common example - calculating group statistics:

```r
# Correct way to calculate mean by group
df %>%
  mutate(
    group_mean = mean(value),
    .by = c(id, date)
  )

# NOT this way:
# df %>%
#   mutate(by = c(id, date), ...)  # This causes the error
```

The key is that `.by` (with a dot) is a parameter of `mutate()`, not a column name.

samples.input:
Add a `name` argument after `dataset` that defaults to the name of the `dataset` object in the calling env.

```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "dir") <- dir

  res
}
```

Store it as a `name` attribute in `res`.

e.g. in:

```
x <- task_create(dataset = eval)
```

`attr(x, "name)` would be `"eval"`.
samples.target:
```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  force(name)
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "name") <- name
  attr(res, "dir") <- dir

  res
}
```

Notably:

* `name` should default to `deparse(substitute(dataset))` or something similar
* `name` needs be `force()`d, or somehow evaluated, before `check_dataset(dataset)` so that the substitution works correctly.
* At some point, the `name` attribute is set to the value.
* The rest of the function should be unaffected, e.g. no comments added to code that existed already.

content.text:
Here's the modified function that captures the name of the `dataset` object from the calling environment:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  check_dataset(dataset)
  
  # If name is not provided, get the name of the dataset object from calling env
  if (is.null(name)) {
    name <- deparse(substitute(dataset))
  }

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "dir") <- dir
  attr(res, "name") <- name

  res
}
```

Now when you call:
```r
x <- task_create(dataset = eval)
```

`attr(x, "name")` will be `"eval"`.

The key is using `deparse(substitute(dataset))` which:
- `substitute()` captures the unevaluated expression passed as the `dataset` argument
- `deparse()` converts that expression to a character string

This allows the function to see what was actually typed as the argument, not just the value it evaluates to.

While the submitted solution would work in practice for the example case, it doesn't follow the exact implementation details required by the criterion. The criterion specifically asks for the default to be set in the function signature and for `force(name)` to be called early to ensure the substitution works correctly.

GRADE: P

events.target:
```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  force(name)
  check_dataset(dataset)

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "name") <- name
  attr(res, "dir") <- dir

  res
}
```

Notably:

* `name` should default to `deparse(substitute(dataset))` or something similar
* `name` needs be `force()`d, or somehow evaluated, before `check_dataset(dataset)` so that the substitution works correctly.
* At some point, the `name` attribute is set to the value.
* The rest of the function should be unaffected, e.g. no comments added to code that existed already.

```

    dataset,

      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))

}

Store it as a `name` attribute in `res`.

e.g. in:

```
x <- task_create(dataset = eval)
```

`attr(x, "name)` would be `"eval"`.

content.text:
Here's the updated function that captures the name of the `dataset` argument:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  check_dataset(dataset)
  
  # Get the name of the dataset object if not provided
  if (is.null(name)) {
    name <- deparse(substitute(dataset))
  }

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "dir") <- dir
  attr(res, "name") <- name

  res
}
```

The key changes:
1. Added `name = NULL` parameter after `dataset`
2. Used `deparse(substitute(dataset))` to capture the name of the object passed to the `dataset` argument when `name` is not explicitly provided
3. Stored the name as an attribute: `attr(res, "name") <- name`

Now in your example:
```r
x <- task_create(dataset = eval)
```
`attr(x, "name")` would indeed be `"eval"`.

content.text:
Here's the updated function that captures the name of the `dataset` argument:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  check_dataset(dataset)
  
  # Get the name if not provided
  if (is.null(name)) {
    name <- deparse(substitute(dataset))
  }

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "dir") <- dir
  attr(res, "name") <- name

  res
}
```

This uses `substitute()` to capture the unevaluated expression passed as the `dataset` argument, and `deparse()` to convert it to a string. If the user provides an explicit `name` argument, that will be used instead.

For your example:
```r
x <- task_create(dataset = eval)
# attr(x, "name") would be "eval"

# Or with explicit name:
y <- task_create(dataset = eval, name = "my_eval_task")
# attr(y, "name") would be "my_eval_task"
```

Here's the updated function that captures the name of the `dataset` argument:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    # TODO: maybe it doesn't need to be associated with a dir at all?
    dir = inspect_log_dir()
) {
  check_dataset(dataset)

  if (is.null(name)) {
    name <- deparse(substitute(dataset))
  }

  dataset$id <- seq_len(nrow(dataset))

  res <-
    structure(
      dataset,
      class = c("task", class(tibble::new_tibble(list())))
    )

  attr(res, "dir") <- dir
  attr(res, "name") <- name

  res
}
```

This uses `substitute()` to capture the unevaluated expression passed as the `dataset` argument, and `deparse()` to convert it to a string. If the user provides an explicit `name` argument, that will be used instead.

```

samples.input: How do I jitter points with ggplot2 only with respect to the x axis, leaving the y values unchanged?

messages.content: How do I jitter points with ggplot2 only with respect to the x axis, leaving the y values unchanged?

content.text:
To jitter points only along the x-axis in ggplot2, you have several options:

## Method 1: Using `geom_point()` with `position_jitter()`

```r
library(ggplot2)

ggplot(data, aes(x = x_var, y = y_var)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

Setting `height = 0` ensures no vertical jittering occurs.

## Method 2: Using `geom_jitter()` directly

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_var, y = y_var)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)
```

## Method 3: Using `position_jitter()` with custom seed

For reproducible jittering:

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x_var, y = y_var)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0, seed = 123))
```

## Example with sample data:

```r
# Create sample data
set.seed(42)
df <- data.frame(
  category = rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 20),
  value = c(rep(10, 20), rep(20, 20), rep(30, 20))
)

# Plot with x-axis jittering only
ggplot(df, aes(x = category, y = value)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0), 
             alpha = 0.6, size = 3) +
  theme_minimal()
```

The `width` parameter controls the amount of horizontal jittering (default is 0.4). Adjust this value based on your needs - smaller values create less spread, larger values create more spread.

messages.content: How do I jitter points with ggplot2 only with respect to the x axis, leaving the y values unchanged?

content.text:
To jitter points only along the x-axis in ggplot2, you can use `position_jitter()` with the `width` parameter set to control horizontal jittering and `height = 0` to prevent vertical jittering.

Here are two approaches:

## Method 1: Using `position_jitter()`

```r
library(ggplot2)

# Example data
set.seed(123)
df <- data.frame(
  x = rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 20),
  y = c(rnorm(20, 10, 1), rnorm(20, 15, 1), rnorm(20, 20, 1))
)

# Plot with x-axis jittering only
ggplot(df, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

## Method 2: Using `geom_jitter()` with height = 0

```r
ggplot(df, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)
```

## For continuous x-axis data:

If your x-axis is continuous rather than categorical, the same approach works:

```r
# Example with continuous x
df2 <- data.frame(
  x = rep(1:3, each = 20),
  y = c(rnorm(20, 10, 1), rnorm(20, 15, 1), rnorm(20, 20, 1))
)

ggplot(df2, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.1, height = 0))
```

## Key parameters:
- `width`: Controls the amount of horizontal jittering (default is 0.4)
- `height`: Set to 0 to prevent vertical jittering
- `seed`: You can set a seed for reproducible jittering with `position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0, seed = 123)`

The `width` value should be adjusted based on your data and the desired amount of separation between points.

messages.content: How do I jitter points with ggplot2 only with respect to the x axis, leaving the y values unchanged?

content.text:
To jitter points only along the x-axis in ggplot2, you have several options:

## Method 1: Using `position_jitter()` with `height = 0`

```r
library(ggplot2)

ggplot(data, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0))
```

Setting `height = 0` ensures no vertical jittering occurs, while `width` controls the horizontal jitter amount.

## Method 2: Using `geom_jitter()` with `height = 0`

```r
ggplot(data, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)
```

This is a shorthand version of the first method.

## Method 3: Using `position_nudge()` with random values

```r
set.seed(123)  # for reproducibility
n <- nrow(data)

ggplot(data, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point(position = position_nudge(x = runif(n, -0.2, 0.2), y = 0))
```

## Example with sample data:

```r
# Create sample data
set.seed(42)
data <- data.frame(
  x = rep(c("A", "B", "C"), each = 20),
  y = c(rnorm(20, 10, 1), rnorm(20, 15, 1), rnorm(20, 20, 1))
)

# Plot with x-axis jitter only
ggplot(data, aes(x = x, y = y)) +
  geom_point(position = position_jitter(width = 0.2, height = 0)) +
  theme_minimal()
```

The `width` parameter controls how much horizontal spread you want. Typical values range from 0.1 to 0.5, depending on your data and visualization needs.

samples.input:
I have some code

```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
...
}
```

I'd like the default name to be the symbol referring to the dataset, e.g. in

```
simple_addition <- tibble(
  input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"),
  target = c("4", "5")
)

tsk <- 
  task_create(
    dataset = simple_addition
  )
```

...the name would be "simple_addition". Instead, it's substituted to `structure(list(input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"), target = c("4", , "5"), id = 1:2), row.names = c(NA, -2L), class = c("tbl_df", , and "tbl", "data.frame"))`. How can I fix that?
samples.target: The `name` default is evaluated lazily, and something else results in `dataset` being evaluated before `name` is. `name` must be evaluated early in the function, e.g. using `force(name)`.

grading.content:
You are assessing a submitted answer on a given task based on a criterion.
[BEGIN DATA]
***
[Task]: I have some code

```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
...
}
```

I'd like the default name to be the symbol referring to the dataset, e.g. in

```
simple_addition <- tibble(
  input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"),
  target = c("4", "5")
)

tsk <- 
  task_create(
    dataset = simple_addition
  )
```

...the name would be "simple_addition". Instead, it's substituted to `structure(list(input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"), target = c("4", , "5"), id = 1:2), row.names = c(NA, -2L), class = c("tbl_df", , and "tbl", "data.frame"))`. How can I fix that?
***
[Submission]: The issue is that `substitute()` is capturing the entire expression after the argument has been evaluated. To get the symbol name of the object passed to the function, you need to use `substitute()` on the formal argument before it gets evaluated.

Here's how to fix it:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  if (is.null(name)) {
    name <- deparse(substitute(dataset))
  }
  # ... rest of your function
}
```

Or, if you want to keep the default argument pattern, you can use a different approach with `match.call()`:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(match.call()$dataset),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  # ... rest of your function
}
```

Another robust approach is to capture the substituted expression immediately:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
  dataset_name <- deparse(substitute(dataset))
  if (is.null(name)) {
    name <- dataset_name
  }
  # ... rest of your function
}
```

All of these approaches will give you `"simple_addition"` as the name when you call:

```r
tsk <- task_create(dataset = simple_addition)
```

The key insight is that `substitute()` needs to be called before the argument is evaluated, which is why putting it directly in the default argument value doesn't work as expected - by the time the default is evaluated, `dataset` has already been resolved to its value.
***
[Criterion]: The `name` default is evaluated lazily, and something else results in `dataset` being evaluated before `name` is. `name` must be evaluated early in the function, e.g. using `force(name)`.
***
[END DATA]

[Submission]: The issue is that `substitute()` is capturing the entire expression after the promise has been forced. To get the symbol name of the argument passed to the function, you need to capture it before the argument is evaluated.

Here's how to fix it:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    if (is.null(name)) {
        name <- deparse(substitute(dataset))
    }
    # ... rest of your function
}
```

Or, if you want to keep the default argument pattern, you can use a bit of non-standard evaluation trickery:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(match.call()$dataset),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    # ... rest of your function
}
```

The `match.call()` approach works because it captures the call as it was made, before argument evaluation.

Another clean approach is to use `rlang::ensym()` if you're already using the rlang package:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    if (is.null(name)) {
        name <- rlang::as_label(rlang::ensym(dataset))
    }
    # ... rest of your function
}
```

scorer_metadata.prompt:
You are assessing a submitted answer on a given task based on a criterion.
[BEGIN DATA]
***
[Task]: I have some code

```
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(substitute(dataset)),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
...
}
```

I'd like the default name to be the symbol referring to the dataset, e.g. in

```
simple_addition <- tibble(
  input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"),
  target = c("4", "5")
)

tsk <- 
  task_create(
    dataset = simple_addition
  )
```

...the name would be "simple_addition". Instead, it's substituted to `structure(list(input = c("What's 2+2?", "What's 2+3?"), target = c("4", , "5"), id = 1:2), row.names = c(NA, -2L), class = c("tbl_df", , and "tbl", "data.frame"))`. How can I fix that?
***
[Submission]: The issue is that `substitute()` is capturing the entire expression after the promise has been forced. To get the symbol name of the argument passed to the function, you need to capture it before the argument is evaluated.

Here's how to fix it:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    if (is.null(name)) {
        name <- deparse(substitute(dataset))
    }
    # ... rest of your function
}
```

Or, if you want to keep the default argument pattern, you can use a bit of non-standard evaluation trickery:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = deparse(match.call()$dataset),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    # ... rest of your function
}
```

The `match.call()` approach works because it captures the call as it was made, before argument evaluation.

Another clean approach is to use `rlang::ensym()` if you're already using the rlang package:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    if (is.null(name)) {
        name <- rlang::as_label(rlang::ensym(dataset))
    }
    # ... rest of your function
}
```

All of these approaches will correctly give you `"simple_addition"` as the name when called with `task_create(dataset = simple_addition)`.
***
[Criterion]: The `name` default is evaluated lazily, and something else results in `dataset` being evaluated before `name` is. `name` must be evaluated early in the function, e.g. using `force(name)`.
***
[END DATA]

```r

    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {

    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    # ... rest of your function
}
```

Note that I'm using `deparse1()` instead of `deparse()` - this is available in R 4.0+ and ensures you get a single character string rather than a character vector.

If you're using an older version of R, you can use:

```r
task_create <- function(
    dataset,
    name = paste(deparse(substitute(dataset)), collapse = ""),
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    # ... rest of your function
}
```

    dataset,
    name = NULL,
    dir = eval_log_dir()
) {
    if (is.null(name)) {
        # Get the call
        call <- match.call()
        # Extract the dataset argument
        name <- deparse1(call$dataset)
    }
    # ... rest of your function
}
```
